speaker: Joe Biden
vclaim: "We created more jobs this past year than the Bush administration in eight years."
date: stated on April 19, 2011 in a speech in Cleveland:
title: Vice President Joe Biden says that more jobs were created last year than all eight years under George Bush.

By Bill McCarthy: 20 January 2021, but Democrats still suffer from "the shadows," he was joking during the April 19 fund-raiser campaign in Cleveland, United States Sun Sherwood Brown, who is facing re-election next year. However, citing positive economic news, Biden insisted that the political debate on his governance policies was now in favour of Democrats. He said, "Many of the things we took shock for, the American public had a chance to take a closer look at now," Paiden noted that the unemployment rate had improved. This comparison added: "We created more jobs this past year than the Bush administration in eight years. We're in a position where we're moving towards creating an average of 220,000 jobs per month. Not enough, but we're moving." Polyte Fact Ohio loves comparisons and decided to study this comparison because it appears as a major democratic dialogue point. When checking job numbers, PolityFact is transferred to the Labour Statistics Office, the official guardian of employment figures in the United States. The figures for this system are based on monthly surveys of employers. It updates the monthly figure with the completion of their surveys by employers and incorporates into the monthly figure a more complete quarterly census of employment and wages. First, we can quickly dispense with the Paiden Initiative: the unemployment rate is improving. In March, the national unemployment rate declined for the fourth consecutive month. By 8.8 per cent, the rate fell from the peak recession of 10.1 in October 2009, according to the BLS Manual. We can also skip the last part: "We are moving towards creating an average of 220,000 jobs per month. Not enough, but we're moving." And since it's not really a statement of facts that includes a prediction, we'll leave it to be examined down the road. But what about comparing Obama's jobs against Bush? The number of posts in February 2001, the first full month of the Bush presidency, was 132.53 million. The number of posts in January 2009, the month he left office, was 133.56 million. This means a net gain of 1.03 million jobs. In order to reverse Baiden ' s claim, we looked back 12 months, from March 2010 to March 2011. (Biden made observations this month, but April figures are yet to be counted.) The number of jobs in March 2010 was 129.43 million. The number of jobs in March 2011 was 130.73 million. The net gain over the past year is 1.3 million jobs. This means that 270,000 jobs have been created in the last 12 months more than the net total of jobs at the end of the Bush term. A familiar turn, or a warning, is in the system. The most recent monthly employment figures for the Labour and Social Security Service are usually preliminary and will change as surveys are completed and figures are updated. This means that the 270,000 edges of Obama's administration can increase -- or disappear. The policy also often indicates that division and timing make all the difference when setting a framework for job numbers. For example, Republicans like to shape the job story in this way: the United States lost a total of 2.09 million jobs since the first full month of Obama's presidency in February 2009. That's right. Of course, looking at this method reduces the impact of Obama ' s deep recession and recent economic growth. Similarly, Bush Democrats are missing when they ignore that the United States created more than 5.6 million jobs until January 2008, when the recession began to take hold. In summary, the recession, which officially began in December 2007, damaged the work record of the two Presidents. Where does that leave Paiden's statement? He is right about the decline in the unemployment rate. It is also accurate in the gains made in the past year. This figure is also in the context of a slow and painful recovery, but the picture of action is improving lately, albeit slowly. An understanding of how job numbers are broken down in its comparison is a point that provides an explanation. In O-Meter's Book of Truth, we classify Paiden's statement as mostly true.
